choices.text: Schizonts are absent in life cycle
Develop only in capillaries of internal organs

questions.text: Why are schizont forms of Plasmodium falciparum rarely seen in peripheral blood smears?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Merozoites released from liver cells infect RBC's.

Inside RBC, they convert into early trophozoite, late trophozoite and Schizont.

Late trophozoite, early and mature schizonts are not found in peripheral blood as this stage occurs inside capillaries of internal organs like spleen, liver and kidney, because P. falciparum has a preference for infecting red blood cells in small capillaries (especially in internal organs).

In these capillaries, schizonts mature and eventually rupture, releasing merozoites into the bloodstream.

Thus, only trophozoite (ring forms) and gametocytes are diagnostic forms present in peripheral blood smear.

Explanation of other options:

Schizonts are absent in the life cycle(Option A): Schizonts are the stage where the parasite divides to produce merozoites, which are released into the bloodstream to infect red blood cells.

Killed by antibodies(Option B): While the immune system plays a role in controlling malaria infection, schizonts are not directly killed by antibodies in the peripheral blood. Antibodies target different stages of the parasite, such as merozoites, gametocytes, or infected red blood cells.

questions.text: Which Plasmodium species preferentially infects young (reticulated) red blood cells (RBCs)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Plasmodium vivax shows a marked preference for infecting young red blood cells (reticulocytes), owing to specific receptors on their surface that facilitate invasion. This selective targeting explains why P. vivax infections are generally less severe than those caused by P. falciparum, though relapses can occur due to hypnozoites persisting in the liver.

After invasion, P. vivax merozoites develop into early trophozoites (ring forms) about 2.5-3 µm in diameter, typically located centrally within the RBC. As they mature into late trophozoites (6-7 µm), the infected RBC must enlarge to accommodate the growing parasite. Consequently, RBCs become pale, enlarged, and irregular, and show characteristic Schüffner's dots (stippling) on microscopy.

Explanation of other options:

Plasmodium falciparum(Option A):Plasmodium falciparum preferentially infects mature red blood cells (RBCs). While P. falciparum can infect a wide range of red blood cells, it primarily targets older RBCs (those in the peripheral blood). Unlike ;P. vivax, which prefers younger cells, P. falciparum can infect any stage of RBC, but does not have a strict preference for young RBCs. It is known to cause the most severe form of malaria, often resulting in complications like cerebral malaria due to the formation of rosettes and sequestration of infected RBCs in small capillaries.

Plasmodium malariae(Option C):Plasmodium malariae does not have a strong preference for young or old red blood cells. It infects mature red blood cells, particularly those that are relatively old. P. malariae tends to cause a chronic infection that can last for many years, even decades, with a relatively low parasitic burden. The infection is usually less severe than P. falciparum, though it can lead to complications like nephrotic syndrome due to the long-term presence of the parasite in the bloodstream.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the technique used in Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC) examination for the identification of malarial parasites?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC) test, 50-100 μl blood is collected in capillaries coated with acridine orange dye (fluorescent dye).
  • It is then centrifuged in a special centrifuge at high speed - 12000 rpm for 5 min.
  • Blood is separated in columns in layers of plasma, buffy coat containing platelets & WBC and RBC.
  • The principle is that infected RBC are less dense than uninfected RBC and concentrate just below the buffy coat at top of the RBC column.
  • As RBC do not contain any nuclear material (DNA & RNA) they are not stained, while nuclei (DNA) of parasites are stained by acridine orange as fluorescing greenish yellow against dark background.

Explanation of other options:

Antigen - Antibody technique (Option A): While antigen-antibody tests (such as rapid diagnostic tests or RDTs) are commonly used for malaria diagnosis, the Quantitative Buffy Coat (QBC) examination is a different technique that does not rely on antigen-antibody interactions. The QBC method involves a concentration of parasites in the buffy coat, which is then examined under the microscope.

Dark ground microscopy(Option B): Dark ground microscopy is typically used for the examination of spirochetes, such as in the diagnosis of syphilis (Treponema pallidum) or Leptospira. This method highlights organisms in a dark background, but it is not used for diagnosing malaria.

Negative staining(Option C): Negative staining is often used in microbiology for visualizing certain bacterial capsules or viruses under the microscope, but it is not the standard technique for detecting malaria parasites. Negative staining highlights the background instead of the organism, which is not typically used for Plasmodium diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic conditions provides some protection against malaria infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Several genetic RBC conditions protect against Plasmodium falciparum malaria, especially in heterozygous individuals.
  • This protection has led to positive selection in malarious regions.
  • G6PD deficiency leads to red blood cell instability under oxidative stress, which can disrupt malaria parasite development. (Option A ruled out)
  • This provides some protection against Plasmodium falciparum infections, though it may cause hemolysis in response to certain triggers.
  • People with sickle cell trait (heterozygous for sickle hemoglobin) have red blood cells that sickle under low oxygen, hindering Plasmodium parasite development.
  • This gives partial protection against malaria, particularly severe forms caused by P. falciparum. (Option B ruled out)
  • Individuals with thalassemia have abnormal or reduced hemoglobin production, leading to premature red blood cell destruction. (Option C ruled out)
  • This reduces the ability of malaria parasites to complete their life cycle in red blood cells, offering protection against severe malaria.
  • Duffy negative RBC lacks glycoprotein receptors required by merozoite to attach and penetrate.
  • Thus duffy negative blood group people are naturally protected from P.vivax.

Explanation:

  • These are all microscopic features used for diagnosis of Plasmodium species in peripheral blood smear.
  • Accole (Applique) formation is a feature of P falciparum. Many times trophozoites of Plasmodium falciparum when inside the RBC, get to the margin of RBC or sometimes project from it creating what is called an Accole. (Option C and D ruled out)
  • RBCs infected with Plasmodium vivax became enlarged, distorted, pale having washed out appearance.
  • RBCs infected with Plasmodium ovale, are oval in shape and have fimbriated margin, while band cell is a feature of Plasmodium malariae infection. (Option B ruled out)

Thin blood smear showing different forms of plasmodium falciparum

(A) Multiple ring form and Accole form (B) Double dot(Head phone shaped ring form) (C) Gametocyte

choices.text: Male & female gametocyte formed in vector and injected inside human body
Merozoite is infective from present in salivary glands of vector
Hypnozoites produced in liver are responsible for relapse in P.vivax
Cerebral malaria and black water fever are complication of P.vivax

questions.text: Which of the following is true about infection by Plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In Plasmodium vivax (and P. ovale), hypnozoites are dormant forms of the parasite that remain in the liver after the initial infection.

These hypnozoites can reactivate weeks, months, or even years later, causing a relapse of malaria.

This is a characteristic feature of P. vivax and P. ovale, as they can cause recurring infections due to the presence of these dormant liver forms.

Explanation of Other options:

Male & female gametocyte formed in vector and injected inside human body
(Option A): Male and female gametocytes are developed inside the humans, and not inside the vector.These gametocytes are ingested by the mosquito during a blood meal, where they undergo sexual reproduction to form sporozoites in the mosquito's gut.

Merozoite is infective from present in salivary glands of vector
(Option B): Sporozoite is the infective form which is present in salivary glands of vectors. These sporozoites are then injected back into the human host during the mosquito's next blood meal.

Cerebral malaria and black water fever are complication of P.vivax
(Option D): Cerebral malaria and black water fever are features of a plasmodium falciparum.

  • Cerebral malariaoccurs when infected red blood cells sequester in the small blood vessels of the brain, blocking blood flow, causing inflammation, and leading to neurological symptoms such as confusion, seizures, and coma. It is life-threatening and requires urgent treatment.
  • Blackwater feveris characterized by massive hemolysis (destruction of red blood cells), often triggered by quinine treatment. This results in the release of hemoglobin into the bloodstream, causing dark-colored urine (hemoglobinuria), jaundice, and potentially acute renal failure.

questions.text: Which of the following findings on a peripheral blood smear provides the most definitive evidence of a prior malarial infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of pigmented monocytes (and macrophages) is the most definitive finding on a peripheral blood smear that indicates a prior or resolving malarial infection.

During an active malaria infection, the parasite Plasmodium digests hemoglobin inside the red blood cell, leaving behind an insoluble waste product called hemozoin (malaria pigment).

When infected red blood cells rupture or are phagocytosed, this hemozoin is released and taken up by monocytes and macrophages in the bloodstream and spleen.

Hemozoin is inert and remains within these cells for weeks to months after the parasites have been cleared.

Explanation of other options:

Shift to the left (Option A): In a blood smear an increased number of immature neutrophils (band cells), usually indicating bacterial infection or inflammatory response, not malaria. It's a common finding in infections like sepsis, but it is not specific to malaria or indicative of previous infection.

Shift to the right (Option B): It refers to an increased number of mature neutrophils, often associated with megaloblastic anemia (due to vitamin B12 or folate deficiency) or liver disease. It is not a feature that would be seen in malaria or as evidence of previous malaria infection.

Anemia (Option D): It can occur during an active malaria infection, but it is not specific to previous infections. Anemia in malaria is primarily due to the destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis) as the parasite matures and ruptures RBCs. While anemia is common during an acute episode, it is not conclusive proof of a previous malaria infection, as it could be a result of the current infection or other causes.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the thick blood smear used for the diagnosis of malaria (Plasmodium infection) is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A thick smear is excellent for detecting the presence of malaria parasites due to its higher sensitivity, it is poor for species differentiation. (Option A ruled out)
  • The process of making a thick smear involves lysing (breaking) the red blood cells and dehemoglobinizing the blood, which distorts the parasite's morphology and destroys the context of the infected red blood cell. This makes it very difficult to see the characteristic features needed to identify the Plasmodium species (e.g., Schüffner's stippling, size and shape of the parasite, number of merozoites in a schizont). For species identification, a thin blood smear is required.

Explanation of other options:

  • More amount of blood required (Option B): A thick smear uses a larger drop of blood (approximately 5-7 µL) compared to a thin smear.
  • Fixation is not required (Option D):A thick smear is air-dried and not fixed with methanol. This allows the red blood cells to lyse during staining, releasing the parasites for concentration. A thin smear, in contrast, must be fixed with methanol to preserve the red blood cell and parasite morphology for species identification.

choices.text: Presence of Ig M antibodies in pregnant woman means her fetus is not at risk of infection
One way to prevent it is, to advise pregnant women not to drink unpasteurized milk

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Toxoplasma gondii infection is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The definitive host for Toxoplasma gondii is cats.

  • The parasite undergoes a sexual method of reproduction in cats, producing oocyst.
  • Oocysts (product of sexual multiplication) excreted in cat feces are infective to man, mammals, birds and rodents like mice.
  • When an intermediate host ingests it along with food or water, oocyst releases sporozoites in the intestine.
  • Sporozoite penetrates intestinal mucosa and multiplies asexually passing through stages of Sporozoite-trophozoite-schizont-merozoite.
  • These merozoites spread via lymphatics and blood to distant organs like the brain, liver, spleen, skeletal muscles and eye.
  • They develop into tissue cysts containing slowly dividing trophozoites (bradyzoites). When such mice containing tissue cysts are eaten by cats, they get infected and the life cycle continues naturally between them.
  • Toxoplasma gondii infection can be acquired through undercooked meat containing tissue cysts, blood transfusion, organ transplant, or transplacental transmission during primary maternal infection, potentially causing congenital toxoplasmosis.

Explanation of other options:

Tissue cyst contains tachyzoites(Option A): Tachyzoites are the active, rapidly dividing form that is found in the acute phase of the infection and is responsible for the spread of the parasite within the host. Tachyzoites typically appear during the early stages of infection, while bradyzoites are the latent, slow-replicating form of the parasite, form when the infection becomes chronic and the parasite enters tissue cysts in the muscles, brain, and other tissues.

Presence of Ig M antibodies in pregnant women means her fetus is not at risk of infection(Option C) : Presence of Ig M antibodies in pregnant women means that she has got an active infection or recent infection and her fetus is at the risk of congenital infection. In contrast, IgG antibodies indicate past exposure and a lower risk of transmitting the infection to the fetus, as the maternal immune system would have developed some protection.

One way to prevent it is, to advise pregnant women not to drink unpasteurized milk(Option D): The mode of infection of Toxoplasma is not through drinking unpasteurized milk.

choices.text: Risk of infection increases with progress of pregnancy
Severity of fetal damage is lowest, when infection transmitted early in pregnancy (first trimester)
Most infected newborns are asymptomatic at birth
Presence of toxoplasma specific IgM antibodies in an infant are suggestive of infection

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman presents for her routine prenatal check-up. She is concerned about the risk of Toxoplasma gondii infection after learning she was exposed to cat feces while cleaning the litter box. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding congenital toxoplasmosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital toxoplasmosis due to transfer of parasites through placenta in utero.

  • The risk of fetal infection rises with the progress of pregnancy.
  • The risk is 25% when the mother acquires primary infection in the first trimester, to 65% in the 3rd trimester.(Option A ruled out)
  • However, the severity of damage is highest, when infection is transmitted early in pregnancy.
  • Early in pregnancy, the fetus is more vulnerable to severe effects such as brain damage, hydrocephalus, and other congenital anomalies, because organogenesis is occurring during this period.
  • Even a small number of organisms can cause significant developmental defects.
  • While the severity of fetal damage decreases as pregnancy progresses, the risk of transplacental transmission increases.

Explanation of other options:

Most infected newborn are asymptomatic at birth(Option C): It is true that most newborns infected with Toxoplasma at birth may be asymptomatic initially. However, symptoms can develop later in life, particularly vision problems or neurological issues, often discovered when the child is several months or years old. Regular follow-up is recommended for newborns diagnosed with congenital toxoplasmosis.

Presence of toxoplasma specific IgM antibodies in an infant are suggestive of infection (Option D) : As IgG antibodies are able to cross the placenta from the mother, presence of toxoplasma specific IgM antibodies synthesized by the fetus because of infection is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 45-year man complains of high-grade fever, malaise and body ache for 4 days. He has recently returned from a vacation in Brazil. Laboratory investigation reveals pancytopenia and decreased hemoglobin. A blood smear shows ring shaped trophozoites inside RBCs. Many RBCs have >1 ring. Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) for HRP-II antigen was negative. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario the patients symptoms, lab findings and the history of recent travel are suggestive of Babesiosis. Babesia are intraerythrocytic coccidian parasites that morphologically resemble plasmodia.

On blood smear, ring-shaped trophozoites within RBCs can resemble Plasmodium falciparum. However, the presence of multiple rings per RBC is much more common in Babesia. The Maltese cross formation (tetrad of merozoites) is a more specific, though not always present, diagnostic feature of babesiosis.

A negative Rapid Antigen Test (RAT) for HRP-II is the key distinguishing clue, since HRP-II is produced exclusively by P. falciparum. With high parasitemia and multiple rings per RBC but negative HRP-II, malaria due to P. falciparum is excluded, and the diagnosis is Babesiosis. (Option A ruled out)

Explanation of other options:

  • falciparum (Option A): This is the most common mimic of babesiosis and can cause high parasitemia. However, the negative HRP-II RAT conclusively excludes it.
  • malariae & P. ovale (Option B and C): These species cause low-level parasitemia. It is extremely rare to see multiple rings per RBC, and they do not cause the degree of parasitemia or severity described.

choices.text: Severe infection can occur in asplenic persons

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with fever, chills, fatigue, and generalized muscle aches. He recently returned from a camping trip in a tick-endemic area in the northeastern United States. Blood smears reveal ring forms inside his red blood cells. His medical history includes a splenectomy performed a few years ago due to trauma. Which of the following statements about the organism causing his symptoms is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypnozoites are dormant forms of certain Plasmodium species (like P. vivax and P. ovale) that can remain in the liver and cause relapse months or years later. However, Babesia species do not form hypnozoites.

  • In babesiosis, relapseis rare and is not mediated by hypnozoites. Instead, recurrence can occur due to incomplete treatment or reinfection, but not through a dormant liver stage.
  • The patient's symptoms and blood smear findings (ring forms inside RBCs) are consistent with Babesiosis, a disease caused by Babesia species.
  • It is important to understand the key characteristics of this parasitic infection to make an accurate diagnosis and treatment plan.
  • Babesia is primarily transmitted by ticks, especially the Ixodes scapularistick, which is found in many parts of the U.S. and Europe.
  • The tick bite transmits the infective stage of the parasite.(Option A ruled out)
  • In Babesia infection, the sporozoitesare the infective forms transmitted to humans through tick bites.
  • These sporozoites infect red blood cells, causing the characteristic symptoms of babesiosis.(Option B ruled out)
  • Asplenic individuals (those who have had a splenectomy, like this patient) are at a much higher risk for severe babesiosis.
  • The spleen plays a critical role in clearing infected red blood cells, and its absence makes individuals more susceptible to severe infections and complications, including hemolytic anemiaand multisystem organ failure.(Option D ruled out)

choices.text: Mode of infection is ingestion of oocyst

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Isospora belli infection is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In Isospora belli infection, diarrhea is usually watery and does not contain blood or mucus. The pathology is due to the parasite invading the intestinal epithelial cells, leading to inflammation, villous atrophy, and malabsorption.
  • Stool in case of Isospora belli infection contains high fecal content, fatty acid crystals and Charcot-Leyden crystals.Most infections are asymptomatic in immunocompetent individuals ( Option B ruled out).
  • However, diarrhea can be protracted, lasting for several years in immunocompromised individuals such as AIDS patients.
  • Humans become infected by ingesting mature oocysts of Isospora belli through contaminated food or water. The oocysts then release sporozoites in the intestine, initiating the infection (Option A ruled out).
  • Isospora belli is one of the few protozoal infections that can be associated with peripheral eosinophilia, particularly in chronic or severe cases ( Option C ruled out).

questions.text: Match the following parasite with their oocyst :
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Opportunistic Protozoal Infections in AIDS:
The four protozoan parasites (Cryptosporidium, Cyclospora, Isospora belli, and Microsporidia) share common features, all cause diarrhea in AIDS patients and appear partially acid-fast on modified acid-fast staining. Differentiation relies on microscopic identification of oocyst morphology in stained stool samples, which is crucial since treatment differs.

  • Isospora belli and Cyclospora → treated with cotrimoxazole.
  • Cryptosporidium → no highly effective drug; paromomycin sometimes used.
  • Microsporidia → managed with albendazole or metronidazole, though therapy is often suboptimal.

choices.text: Main reservoir of infection is man

questions.text: Which of the following statements is most accurate for Balantidium coli?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The drug of choice for treating balantidiasis, the infection caused by Balantidium coli, is tetracycline.

  • The primary reservoir for Balantidium coli is pigs. Humans are an accidental host, and human-to-human transmission, while possible, is less common than transmission from pigs or contaminated water.(Option A ruled out)
  • Balantidium coli has a simple two-stage life cycle: the active, invasive trophozoite and the dormant, infectious cyst. The cyst is the form responsible for transmission, as it can survive in the environment and is infective when ingested.(Option B ruled out)
  • Excystation occurs in the small intestine, trophozoite released reaches to the large intestine, penetrates the intestinal mucosal cell and causes ulceration, resembling amebiasis.
  • Balantidium coli is the largest protozoan parasite inhabiting the large intestine.(Option D ruled out)
  • It is effective in treating the intestinal infection and reducing symptoms, though other drugs like metronidazolecan also be used in some cases.

choices.text: Reproduce in cell by spore formation
Demonstrated by hematoxylin and eosin stain

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not accurate for Microsporidia species ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Microsporidia are unicellular, spore-forming, obligate intracellular parasites that were previously classified as protozoa but are now placed under the fungal phylum Microspora ( Option A is ruled out).
  • Due to their intracellular location, they are not easily visualized on routine hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) stains.
  • Instead, modified trichrome, modified acid-fast, Gram stain, and calcofluor white are preferred for identifying spores in clinical samples.
  • There are over 1200 known species, but 13 species across 3 genera (especially Enterocytozoon bieneusi and Encephalitozoon spp.) are known to infect humans, particularly those who are immunocompromised, such as HIV/AIDS patients.
  • The entire life cycle occurs within the host cell. They undergo a complex life cycle (merogony, sporogony) that culminates in the production of the environmentally resistant spores, which are the infectious stage. (Option B is ruled out).
  • Infection occurs via ingestion or inhalation of spores, which use a polar filament to inject their sporoplasm into host cells, a process likened to "nature's perfect syringe."
  • While the most common manifestation is diarrhea, Microsporidia can also cause extraintestinal infections, including sinusitis, bronchiolitis, cholangitis, keratoconjunctivitis, and even disseminated disease (Option C is ruled out).
  • Diagnosis is made by special staining techniques, and treatment includes fumagillin for E. bieneusi and albendazole for systemic infections. Immune recovery with antiretroviral therapy is crucial for resolution in HIV patients.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with AIDS presents to a clinic with chronic, intractable, debilitating diarrhea. He gave a history of returning from a camping trip recently. Smear prepared from stool was positive with modified acid-fast stain. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In the given clinical scenario the patient's symptoms and the lab findings are suggestive of Cryptosporidium parvum infection.It is an opportunistic parasitic infection in AIDS patients which produce chronic intractable diarrhea lasting for more than 1 month.

Cryptosporidium parvum is a protozoan parasite that causes profuse, watery diarrhea, typically self-limiting in immunocompetent individuals, but severe and chronic in immunocompromised patients such as those with AIDS.

Transmission occurs through ingestion of contaminated water or food, with symptoms resembling those of Giardia lamblia but more severe and persistent in vulnerable populations.

Diagnosis is made by identifying acid-fast oocysts in stool or via immunofluorescence and PCR techniques.

Modified acid-fast stain:

  • The modified acid-fast stainis used to detect oocysts of Cryptosporidium in stool samples. Cryptosporidium oocysts appear red or pink on this stain, confirming the diagnosis.

There is no uniformly effective treatment, but agents like paromomycin and octreotide may reduce symptoms. Prevention focuses on safe water practices and protecting high-risk individuals from exposure.

Nitrazoxanide, a synthetic drug, has been approved for use in all patients over 1 year of age in the United States

Explanation of other options:

Entamoeba histolytica (Option A): This parasite causes amoebic dysentery, characterized by bloody diarrhea and tissue invasion, not typically chronic, intractable diarrhea in AIDS patients. It does not stain with the modified acid-fast technique.

Giardia lamblia (Option B): Giardia causes watery diarrhea ;and gastrointestinal symptoms, but it is usually self-limiting and less commonly causes chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals compared to Cryptosporidium. Giardia cysts are detected by fecal antigen tests or stool microscopy, not by acid-fast stain.

Balantidium coli (Option C): This is a ;ciliate parasite that can cause dysentery, but it is much less common in AIDS patients and does not typically present with chronic diarrhea. It is also not detected with the modified acid-fast stain.

questions.text: An 8 -year-old child living in a rural area of Africa, contracts an illness that is initially characterized by vomiting and periods of moderate fever. Over the next few days, his condition dramatically worsens, he becomes markedly lethargic, and his fever intensifies to the point of delirium and convulsions. Peripheral blood smear reveals the infective agent (shown in the image). What is the cause of this child's illness?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The description of the child's clinical course-intense fever, lethargy, delirium, and convulsions along with peripheral blood smear picture findings of the double ring trophozoites (stereo headphone) and Accole formation due to attachment of ring to RBC margin along with lack of erythrocytic Schuffner's dots are consistent with severe malaria caused by P. falciparum.

p. falciparum is the most dangerous species of Plasmodium and is responsible for the majority of severe malaria cases, It can cause cerebral malaria, which presents with altered mental status, delirium, and seizures.

p. falciparum also causes hyperparasitemia, with a high level of infected red blood cells in the circulation, which leads to severe complications such as organ failure and death f untreated.

Cerebral malaria occurs when infected red blood cells sequester in the small blood vessels of the brain, blocking blood flow, causing inflammation, and leading to neurological symptoms such as confusion, seizures, and coma.

It is life-threatening and requires urgent treatment

Explanation of other options:

P. vivax (Option A ):It typically causes milder malaria than falciparum. It usually leads to fever and chills, with paroxysms every 48 hours, and does not commonly cause severe complications like cerebral malaria or seizures.It makes the RBCs enlarged, Schuffner's dots and doesn't show multiple rings in single RBC.

P. malariae (Option C): This species typically causes milder illness with fever every 72 hours, not severe complications like cerebral malaria.

Babesia(Option D): Babesiosis is transmitted by ticks, not mosquitoes, and causes milder symptom s like fever and anemia, but not delirium or seizures as seen in this case.
